page.title: 02The Landscape.
page.content: On the top heather predominates over bracken and grass and there are large patches of bare granite due to fires in the 1930s.These fires also revealed extensive Bronge Age settlement. Gannet's Combe,however,a wide and shallow valley to the east, has deep marshy vegetation. At the N.W.point is Lundy North Light. The remains of a tramway and winch can be seen which used to raise supplies when the lighthouse was manned-and a steep flight of steps winds its way, past Kittiwake Gully,to the sea below. Off-shore are the treacherous rocks The Hen and Chickens,through which the tide-race roars. Telegraph posts once carried the link to the south of the island but these were used recently to fuel a beacon. The exposed west coast is particularly rugged and bare.
